header.title: GitCMS
header.excerpt: What started as a quest for the perfect database for my portfolio spiraled into building a universal Git-powered Content Management System with a slick admin panel. This is my journey from database drama to inventing my own... GitCMS!

data.overview: A universal, GitHub-based Content Management System. It merges Git’s reliability with a modern admin interface, featuring dynamic schemas, zero configuration setup, and a Next.js dashboard.
data.content:
GitCMS: when my Portfolio accidentally became Infrastructure

The Problem I Didn't Mean to Solve

Building a portfolio should be simple. Pick a template, add some projects, write a few blog posts, deploy. Done.

But I wanted something different. I was building Magic Portfolio, a fully 3D, interactive experience that would feel alive while being completely static.

No servers, no APIs, just pure frontend magic. The kind of project where every detail matters, where the line between "functional" and "beautiful" blurs into something more ambitious.

And then I hit the content problem.

How do you manage dynamic content like projects, blog posts and collaborations in a static site?

Hard-code everything in JavaScript? Sure, until the fifth time you need to update a date or fix a typo.

Use a traditional CMS? Now you need a backend, a database, deployment pipelines, and suddenly your "simple portfolio" requires the infrastructure of a small startup.

So I did what any developer would do: I went database shopping.

The Great Database Pilgrimage

Supabase: The Shiny New Toy

Supabase looked perfect on paper. Auto-generated APIs, real-time updates, a slick dashboard, TypeScript types out of the box, and built-in auth. It was like the Swiss Army knife of databases.

But then reality set in.

The free tier caught my attention, not for what it offered, but for what it didn't:

  • 500MB database limit.

  • Projects paused after 1 week of inactivity. Imagine explaining to users that they don’t see your content because you need to manually restart your portfolio from a dashboard every week.

  • No backups.

  • Limit of 2 projects. What if I needed three?

And then came the elephant in the room: vendor lock-in and scaling costs to avoid the free tier limitations. All that just to keep a free portfolio online. There had to be a better way.

The Other Contenders

Notion API: Beautiful UI, terrible API. Rate limits that made me nervous, rigid structures that fought against me, and the constant fear that Notion would change something overnight and break everything.

PostgreSQL + Prisma: The control freak's paradise. Absolute power, absolute responsibility. I wanted to build a portfolio, not become a DevOps engineer managing servers and backups at 2 AM.

Firebase/Firestore: Fast, scalable, real-time... and another flavor of vendor lock-in with costs that could spiral easily.

File System + Git: The old-school rebel. Markdown files, JSON data, versioned by Git, backed up by default, zero vendor lock-in. Fast, offline-friendly, total control. The only problem? Editing content felt like hacking the Matrix.

The "Aha" Moment

Then it hit me.

What if I didn't have to choose? What if I could have the flexibility and control of the file system, the versioning and backup magic of Git, and the user-friendliness of a modern admin panel?

What if GitHub itself could be the database?

Not in the "technically you could" sense, but in the "this should be frictionless" sense. A beautiful UI where you manage content like a pro, with intuitive forms, rich text editing, drag-and-drop media uploads and easy content type management.

All stored as files in your GitHub repository, with the power to fetch that content from a simple SDK in any project.

That's when GitCMS stopped being a solution for my portfolio and started becoming something bigger.

From Idea to Architecture

The Vision Takes Shape

The concept was deceptively simple: GitHub as a content management system.

But simple concepts hide complex challenges.

I didn't want to build a markdown editor with Git integration. I wanted universal infrastructure, something so generic it works for web projects, mobile apps, documentation sites, blogs, portfolios, e-commerce catalogs, whatever you dream up.

Something that dissolves the artificial boundary between "development" and "content management".

Building the Monorepo

GitCMS grew into three core pieces, each solving a specific problem:

The Shared Foundation: @git-cms/core

The core package is the invisible glue: schema validation with Zod, Git LFS handling for large files, media organization utilities, GitHub API abstractions.

The Admin Panel: @git-cms/admin

A Next.js application that's the opposite of traditional CMS installations.

Instead of everyone self-hosting their own instance, there's one universal hosted interface at gitcms-admin.bestplayer.dev. Sign in with GitHub OAuth, connect any repository (public or private), and start managing content.

The UI needed to be invisible: so intuitive that a content creator shouldn't need to think about Git, commits, or file structures.

Behind the scenes, TipTap powers a rich text editor that rivals WordPress, with support for images, videos, tables, code blocks, and custom formatting. Every action, like creating a post, uploading an image and defining a schema, translates to a Git commit, but users never see that complexity.

The Developer SDK: @git-cms/client

The client SDK is where the developer experience lives.

A TypeScript-first library that treats GitHub like a queryable database:

const cms = new GitCMS({ repository: 'username/blog' });
const posts = await cms
    .from('posts')
    .where('metadata.status', '==', 'published')
    .where('featured', true)
    .orderBy('metadata.publishedAt', 'desc')
    .limit(10)
    .get();

It looks like Firestore, but it's reading files from GitHub.

The magic is in the abstraction: developers get type-safe queries, nested field access with dot notation, progressive media loading, and framework-agnostic integration, whether you're building with React, Vue, Next.js, or vanilla JavaScript.

And the killer feature? For public repositories, it requires zero backend.

No API server, no authentication proxy, no deployment complexity. Just install the package and start fetching content. For private repos, the SDK supports secure token-based authentication, but always on the server side, never exposing credentials to browsers.

All the unglamorous infrastructure that makes both the admin panel and client SDK work seamlessly.

Key Design Principles

1. Git as the Source of Truth

No separate database layer. No sync conflicts. No "last write wins" disasters. Git's commit history becomes the audit log and branches become preview environments.

2. Type Safety Everywhere

Content validation happens at write time in admin, thanks to the dynamic UI for content form, catching errors before they reach users.

3. Progressive Enhancement for Media

Media loading uses a two-stage approach:

  • Fast Render: embedded base64 thumbnails show instantly

  • Full Render: high-resolution images and videos load asynchronously

Users see content immediately, and quality improves progressively. For videos and documents, this means showing placeholder posters or icons first, then enabling full playback or downloads only when needed.

4. Zero Vendor Lock-In

Everything is just files in your repository. Don't like GitCMS anymore? Fine.

Your content is already in a standard format (JSON) in a Git repo you own: export it, transform it, migrate it. No proprietary database to wrestle with!

The Hard Parts (what they don't tell you about simple ideas)

Challenge 1: GitHub OAuth and Security

Implementing OAuth is straightforward until you realize the admin panel handles potentially hundreds of users, each with different repositories, different permissions, and different security requirements.

Tokens must stay server-side. Sessions must be encrypted. Token refresh has to be bulletproof.

And then there's the rate limiting dance: 60 requests/hour for unauthenticated requests, 5,000/hour for authenticated. The SDK needed to be smart about caching, batching, and detecting which mode to use without bothering the developer.

Challenge 2: Schema Inference vs. Validation

How do you let users define any content structure they want while maintaining type safety? The answer: a visual schema designer in the admin panel that generates JSON schemas, which the core package validates with Zod, and the client SDK interprets for TypeScript types.

But making that schema designer intuitive, i.e. letting people add fields, choose types, set validation rules and understand nested structures without requiring them to learn JSON Schema syntax? That took iteration.

Challenge 3: Making File-Based Content Feel Like a Database

Reading files from GitHub is easy. Making it feel like querying a database, with filters, sorting, pagination and nested field access required building a query engine that:

  • Fetches efficiently (minimize API calls)

  • Filters locally (avoid fetching everything)

  • Handles nested dot notation metadata.author.name

  • Supports multiple operators ==, >, in, contains, …

  • Returns type-safe results

Every query optimization were engineering trade-offs that users would never see but would absolutely feel.

Challenge 4: Building for Everyone (literally)

GitCMS couldn't be tied to a framework. React developers, Vue developers, Next.js users, Svelte enthusiasts, even vanilla JavaScript projects… everyone needed first-class support. That meant:

  • No framework-specific dependencies in the SDK

  • Server-side and Client-side compatibility

  • Support for both ESM and CommonJS

  • Comprehensive TypeScript types without forcing TypeScript

What It's Like to Use GitCMS

For Content Creators

Imagine opening gitcms-admin.bestplayer.dev, signing in with GitHub (one click), and connecting your portfolio repo.

Then you define a "Project" schema: title, description, URL, images, featured flag. GitCMS generates a form.

You create your first project entry. TipTap's editor lets you format descriptions with bold, italic, lists, code blocks. You drag and drop a screenshot. Behind the scenes, GitCMS uploads the image to your repo's media folder and embeds it.

You click "Publish" and in under two seconds your changes are committed to GitHub.

The entire content management experience feels like Notion or WordPress, but you're editing files in Git, and you didn't need to configure anything.

For Developers

In your Next.js portfolio, you install the SDK:

npm install @git-cms/client

Initialize the client:

const cms = new GitCMS({ repository: 'username/portfolio' });

Fetch projects:

const projects = await cms
    .from('projects')
    .where('featured', true)
    .orderBy('date', 'desc')
    .get();

The SDK returns data structured exactly as you defined it in the admin panel! You map over projects and render them in your components.

Images load fast (thumbnails) then upgrade to full resolution. Videos show posters with play buttons. Everything is cached intelligently.

When a content creator publishes a new project, your site fetches fresh data. No backend deployment. No database migration. Just content, version-controlled, always in sync.

For Magic Portfolio

Magic Portfolio consumes GitCMS content seamlessly. Projects, blog posts, work-in-progress updates: they're all fetched via the SDK and rendered in a 3D environment. The portfolio feels dynamic because content updates flow from Git, but there's zero server infrastructure.

It's the perfect synthesis: the power of a CMS without the complexity of traditional backends.

Why It Matters

Reclaiming Simplicity

Modern web development has become absurdly complex. To build a blog, you're told you need a database, a backend, an API, a deployment pipeline, monitoring, logging, backups, and scaling strategies. GitCMS says: what if you didn't?

What if content could just be files?

What if version control was built-in because Git exists?

What if "hosting" meant pushing to GitHub?

What if the entire stack was free, transparent, and portable?

Merging Development and Content

There's an artificial wall between "code" and "content." Developers work in Git; content creators work in CMSs. GitCMS erases that boundary. Everything lives in the same repository.

Content becomes part of the codebase, not a separate concern. And that unlocks workflows that traditional CMSs can't touch.

Bringing Control Back to Creators

With traditional CMSs, you're renting. You don't own your data; you lease access to it. Pricing changes, features disappear, companies shut down, and you scramble to export and migrate.

With GitCMS, your content is already in Git. It's already backed up. It's already versioned. It's already yours.

If GitCMS vanishes tomorrow, you lose a UI, but your content remains intact, fully functional, ready to consume with a few lines of code.

What's Next

GitCMS is live, functional, and powering real projects (at least my portfolio). But the journey is far from over.

On the Roadmap

Multi-Repository Support: Manage content across multiple repos from one admin interface. Perfect for agencies or developers juggling several client projects.

Collaborative Editing: Real-time collaboration, content review workflows, and role-based permissions. Make GitCMS a true team platform.

GitLab and Bitbucket Compatibility: GitHub is the starting point, but the architecture is adaptable. Expanding to other Git platforms makes GitCMS truly universal.

Full-Text Search: Client-side search across all content without external services. Fast, privacy-respecting, and offline-capable.

Branch-Based Workflows: Edit content on separate branches, preview changes, and merge via pull requests. Content management meets modern development practices.

Webhooks and Integrations: Trigger rebuilds, send notifications, integrate with CI/CD pipelines. GitCMS as infrastructure, not just a content layer.

The Bigger Picture

GitCMS is part of something greater: can infrastructure be simple again?

Not simple as in "toy projects only", but simple as in "powerful without being overwhelming". Simple as in "solves real problems without creating new ones". Simple as in "you understand how it works because there's nothing hidden".

It's a response to the bloat of modern development, where every solution demands five more dependencies, three configuration files, and a dedicated DevOps engineer.

Today, building something meaningful often feels impossible unless you have the budget of a venture-backed startup.

Sometimes, the best tools are the ones that get out of your way and just let you build.

Reflections

Building GitCMS taught me more than I expected. It wasn't just about learning GitHub APIs, optimizing query engines, or designing intuitive UIs. It was about understanding trade-offs.

Every feature I added was a trade-off.

Type safety versus flexibility.

Simplicity versus power.

Convention versus configuration.

Hosting a universal admin panel versus letting users self-host.

I chose universal hosting because onboarding should be one click, not a tutorial. I chose Git as the source of truth because transparency beats convenience. I chose a monorepo because modularity enables reuse. I chose TypeScript because correctness catches bugs before users see them.

GitCMS reminded me that sometimes, the best systems aren't the most complex, but the ones that quietly work behind the scenes, making creativity flow naturally.

The ones that dissolve into the background and let you focus on what you're building, not the infrastructure holding it up.

Magic Portfolio needed a content layer. I built GitCMS. And in doing so, I created something that extends far beyond a single project. A tool that others can use, modify, and build upon.

That's the part that makes this worth it. Not the technical challenges or the architectural elegance or the lines of code. It's the idea that someone, somewhere, might use GitCMS to bring their own project to life. To avoid the database drama I went through. To focus on their work instead of wrestling with infrastructure.

If GitCMS becomes that tool for even one person, then building it was time well spent.

Try It Yourself

GitCMS is open source and ready to use:

- Admin Panel: https://gitcms-admin.bestplayer.dev

- Client SDK: npm install @git-cms/client

- GitHub: BestPlayerMMIII/GitCMS

- Documentation: https://gitcms-docs.bestplayer.dev

Whether you're building a blog, a portfolio, a documentation site, or something entirely unexpected, GitCMS is here to make content management feel less like a chore and more like a natural part of your workflow.

Welcome to Git-based content management. Welcome to simplicity with power.

Welcome to GitCMS.

Cool Fact

This article was written through the GitCMS admin panel (the same tool I'm describing) running on localhost.

Meta? Absolutely.

Functional? Even better.
